title: My Weird Winter Skin Thing and the Pineapple Tallow Balm That Fixed It
body:
Okay so my face feels like a potato. A cold, dry potato. That’s the winter skincare vibe right now. It’s that specific kind of dry where you can almost hear your skin crackling when you smile. The air in my apartment is so dry from the heater, I swear it’s stealing moisture directly from my cheeks. And my hands? Forget it. They look like I’ve been digging in chalk dust. This happens every single year. My skin just gives up. It’s like it goes on strike from November to March and I’m left negotiating with a flaky, tight, angry committee that lives on my face.

I was scrolling on my phone one night, probably around 11 PM, my knuckles looking all red and sad, and I kept seeing stuff about tallow balm. Beef fat. For your face. I mean, come on. It sounded like something my great-grandma would have used, not a thing you buy on the internet in 2024. But I was desperate. I’d tried that fancy hyaluronic acid serum that costs like eighty bucks. I’d tried the thick ceramide creams that sit on top of your skin like a greasy mask. Nothing worked. Or it worked for an hour and then my skin was thirsty again. So I figured, what’s the weirdest thing I could try? Beef tallow skincare. Why not. I found this little Etsy shop that made it, and they had a Pineapple scent. Winter was feeling very beige and gray, so the idea of something called “tropical escape” was too good to pass up. I ordered the Whipped Tallow Balm. From France, apparently. Made from grass-fed beef suet. My brain was having a hard time computing all this.

It showed up in a little box. I opened it in my kitchen, the overhead light was way too bright. My cat was watching me. Judging, probably.

## What Using Beef Tallow on Your Face is Actually Like

So the jar is small. Cute. I unscrewed the lid and poked it. The texture is… weird. Not bad weird. It’s whipped, so it’s like this super dense, kind of fluffy cream? But also solid? I don’t know how to describe it. You scoop a tiny bit and it melts the second it hits your finger. I was braced for it to smell like beef broth or a kitchen. It doesn’t. It smells like pineapple. But not like candy pineapple, or cleaning product pineapple. It’s like… if you walked past a fruit stand on a hot day. That’s the closest I can get. Sweet fruit, but not fake. Cheerful. It made me think of sunscreen, in a good way. Vacation feeling, for sure.

I rubbed a little between my palms. It turned into this silky oil almost instantly. I patted it all over my dry potato face, half expecting to break out in hives or for my partner to walk in and ask why I was marinating myself. But it just… sank in. Like, really fast. No greasy film. My skin just drank it. It felt calm. Not “moisturized” in that heavy, coated way. Just… normal. Like my skin forgot it was supposed to be freaking out. That was the first surprise.

The second surprise was my hands. After I did my face, I had this tiny bit left on my palms, so I just rubbed it into the backs of my hands. The next morning, the little dry cracks near my thumb were less angry. Not gone, but softer. Like they’d decided to take the day off from hurting. I started using it on my hands every night after that. And my elbows, which are always a disaster. I keep the jar on my nightstand now, next to my water glass and a pile of random receipts.

## Why This Stuff Works When Winter is the Worst

I looked it up later because I was curious. Why would this work? Turns out beef tallow is structurally really similar to the oils our own skin makes. That sebum stuff. So it doesn’t just sit on top like a foreign object—your skin recognizes it and absorbs it deep. It mimics human skin sebum. That’s the sciencey reason, I guess. My non-sciencey reason is that it doesn’t fight with my skin. It’s not a fancy chemical trying to trick it. It’s just… giving it back what the dry winter air and the blasting heater stole. It’s a replenishment, not a cover-up.

My routine now is stupid simple. I wash my face with water in the morning. At night, maybe a gentle cleanser if I wore makeup. Then I scoop a pea-sized amount of this pineapple tallow balm, warm it up, and pat it in. That’s it. Sometimes I put a tiny dot on my lips before bed too. It’s good for chapped lips, apparently. And it is. Wakes up smooth.

I should probably order another jar soon. I’m maybe halfway through this one and I’ve had it since… December? I think? Time is fake in winter. But I use it every single day. It’s become the thing I do without thinking. The ritual of it is nice. Cold jar, warm hands, that little hit of pineapple smell. It’s a two-second vacation. My skin hasn’t felt tight in weeks. Not even when I first step outside and the wind hits. That’s the real test.

## Would I Buy This Pineapple Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already am. I’m getting one for my mom. Her hands get so dry in winter from washing dishes, and she hates the feeling of lotion. I think she’ll like this because it disappears. It doesn’t leave her hands slippery. And the scent is just happy. It’s not a perfume-y smell that lingers. It’s just there when you open the jar, and then it’s gone on your skin.

Is it a miracle? No. It’s a balm. But it’s the first thing that’s actually made a difference for my dry winter skin without making me feel like I’m wearing a mask or spending a fortune. I didn’t expect much from a jar of whipped beef fat, but honestly, it works. My face doesn’t feel like a potato anymore. It just feels like my face. A little happier, maybe. And my elbows are… presentable. That’s a win.

Anyway, if your skin is being difficult this season, and everything else feels like it’s just pretending to work, this might be worth a shot. It’s a weird concept that turned out to be not weird at all. Just simple. And sometimes simple is what actually fixes the problem.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, I think so. It sounds wild, but it makes sense when you read about it. It’s really close to the oils our skin already makes, so it gets absorbed deep instead of sitting on top. It’s like giving your skin back what the weather steals.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And I can get clogged pores pretty easy. It absorbs fast. It’s not like slathering on Vaseline or something. It feels more like a dry oil. Sinks right in.

**What does the Pineapple tallow balm smell like?**
It’s like fresh pineapple, but not in a sugary way. More like the smell of a ripe fruit. It’s bright and sweet and makes me think of summer. The scent doesn’t really stick around on your skin, which I like. It’s just a nice little moment when you’re putting it on.
random_tangent: I should probably order another jar soon
